newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian August prices fall but problems ahead.
newsitem.headline: Russian August prices fall but problems ahead.

text.p: Russian consumer prices fell in August for the first time since economic reforms began in 1992 but economists said the good news masked problems ahead for firms, banks and individuals.
They said that tight monetary policy had dragged inflation down but low tax payments, high inter-enterprise debt and mounting wage arrears were bad signs for the future.

"If the government can manage not to spend what it promised to spend, then we could have 20 percent (year-on-year) inflation this year but it's not the low-inflation, high-growth economy that you are looking for," said one Western investment analyst.
"It's a sign of ill-health rather than of potential good health."
The state statistics committee said consumer prices fell 0.2 percent in August after a rise of 0.7 percent in July.
Year-on-year inflation data for August is not yet available but the committee said consumer prices had risen 16.1 percent since the start of the year.
If the current negative price trend continued, annual inflation could be as low as 15 percent, it said. Consumer prices rose 131 percent year-on-year in December 1995.
Economists said seasonal factors -- low food prices and holiday absences -- were also behind the August price fall.
But some said the low rate could hurt fragile Russian banks, which need high inflation and high interest rates to stay afloat.

"Everybody expects that inflation will not be as low as in August in coming months but it will nevertheless be low, and that could lead to a banking crisis in Russia in the fall," said Sergei Markov, analyst with the Carnegie Institute.
Discontent with reforms is growing and millions of workers have not been paid for months.
Companies blame other firms which do not pay for deliveries but weak bankruptcy laws and an inefficient legal system mean there is little they can do to make people pay.

The battle against inflation has been one of Russia's toughest fights since it launched its economic reforms in January 1992. The August figure will be welcome news to a government under pressure on other fronts.
Tax collection is running well behind schedule and the government will face a struggle to get its tight 1997 budget through a parliament dominated by communists and other conservatives.
The budget envisages a deficit of 3.3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), after a forecast 3.85 percent gap this year.
The International Monetary Fund postponed handing over the July tranche of a three-year $10 billion loan to Russia because of concern about Moscow's ability to meet the 1996 budget.
But the money was handed over last month and the IMF is expected to approve the August tranche of the loan soon.
Officials working with the Russian finance ministry say the IMF also revised up its target for the Russian budget deficit to 5.25 percent of GDP from four percent.
Russia and the IMF use different methodology to calculate the budget deficit.
